title: Petroleum Engineering (PE)
description: Comprehensive GATE Petroleum Engineering assessment covering General Aptitude and Core Petroleum Engineering subjects. This assessment includes 10 aptitude questions (15% weight) and 55 core petroleum engineering questions (85% weight) following the official GATE pattern.
whatIsDescription: GATE (Graduate Aptitude Test in Engineering) Petroleum Engineering is a national-level examination that primarily tests the comprehensive understanding of various undergraduate subjects in petroleum engineering and related fields. This assessment follows the official GATE pattern with General Aptitude and Core Petroleum Engineering questions.

typicalCareers.title: Petroleum Engineer
typicalCareers.description: Advanced petroleum engineering positions in oil and gas industry

typicalCareers.title: PhD Candidate
typicalCareers.description: Pursue higher studies in petroleum engineering and related fields

typicalCareers.title: Reservoir Engineer
typicalCareers.description: Senior technical roles in reservoir management and optimization

whoShouldConsider: Petroleum Engineering graduates preparing for GATE
Students seeking admission to M.Tech/M.E programs in petroleum engineering
Professionals looking for PSU jobs in petroleum sector
Researchers in petroleum engineering and related fields
idealTraits: Solid foundation in petroleum engineering fundamentals
Good understanding of reservoir mechanics and drilling operations

modules: Core Petroleum Engineering Assessment (55 questions, 85 marks)

aptitude.title: General Aptitude Assessment
aptitude.description: Test your general aptitude including verbal ability, quantitative aptitude, and analytical reasoning skills. This section carries 15% weight in the total assessment.

questions.text: If the ratio of boys to girls in a class is 3:2 and there are 15 boys, how many girls are there?
questions.subject: Numerical Ability - Ratio
questions.explanation: If ratio is 3:2, then boys/girls = 3/2. Given boys = 15, so 15/girls = 3/2, girls = (15 × 2)/3 = 10.

questions.text: Choose the word that is most similar in meaning to "ABUNDANT".
questions.subject: Verbal Ability - Synonyms
questions.explanation: Abundant means existing in large quantities; plentiful is the closest synonym.

questions.text: If all roses are flowers and some flowers fade quickly, which statement must be true?
questions.subject: Logical Reasoning - Syllogism
questions.explanation: Since all roses are flowers and some flowers fade quickly, it is possible that some roses are among those flowers that fade quickly.

questions.text: A train travels 120 km in 2 hours. What is its average speed in m/s?
questions.subject: Numerical Ability - Speed
questions.explanation: Speed = 120 km / 2 hrs = 60 km/hr. Converting to m/s: 60 × 1000 / 3600 = 16.67 m/s.

options.text: Neither of the students have completed their homework
Neither of the students has completed their homework
Neither of the students have completed his homework
Neither of the student has completed their homework

questions.subject: Verbal Ability - Grammar
questions.explanation: "Neither" is singular and takes "has". "Their" is acceptable for gender-neutral reference.

questions.text: If A is taller than B, and B is taller than C, which statement is definitely true?
questions.subject: Logical Reasoning - Transitivity
questions.explanation: By transitive property: A > B and B > C, therefore A > C.

questions.text: Choose the word opposite in meaning to "EXPAND".
questions.subject: Verbal Ability - Antonyms
questions.explanation: Expand means to increase in size; contract means to decrease in size.

questions.text: A man buys an item for ₹50 and sells it for ₹60. What is his profit percentage?
questions.subject: Numerical Ability - Profit and Loss

core.title: Core Petroleum Engineering Assessment
core.description: Comprehensive assessment of core petroleum engineering subjects including Reservoir Engineering, Drilling Engineering, Production Engineering, Petroleum Geology, and related topics. This section carries 85% weight in the total assessment.

questions.text: What is the primary component of natural gas?
questions.subject: Petroleum Geology - Natural Gas
questions.explanation: Methane (CH₄) is the primary component of natural gas, typically comprising 70-90% of its composition.

questions.text: The SI unit of permeability is:
questions.subject: Reservoir Engineering - Permeability
questions.explanation: In SI units, permeability is measured in m². The commonly used unit in petroleum engineering is Darcy (1 Darcy ≈ 9.87 × 10⁻¹³ m²).

questions.text: Which type of trap is formed by folding of rock layers?
questions.subject: Petroleum Geology - Traps
questions.explanation: Anticlinal traps are structural traps formed by upward folding of rock layers into an arch shape.

options.text: Density of crude oil relative to water

questions.subject: Petroleum Properties - API Gravity
questions.explanation: API (American Petroleum Institute) gravity is an inverse measure of petroleum liquid density relative to water. Higher API gravity indicates lighter (less dense) crude oil.

questions.text: In a reservoir, porosity is defined as:

options.text: The ability of rock to transmit fluids
The ratio of pore volume to bulk volume
The pressure gradient in the formation

questions.subject: Reservoir Engineering - Porosity
questions.explanation: Porosity (φ) is the ratio of pore volume to total bulk volume of the rock, expressed as a fraction or percentage.

questions.text: Which drilling fluid property helps in carrying cuttings to surface?
questions.subject: Drilling Engineering - Drilling Fluids
questions.explanation: Viscosity provides the carrying capacity for drill cuttings. Higher viscosity helps suspend and transport cuttings to the surface.

questions.text: The bubble point pressure is the pressure at which:

options.text: First bubble of gas appears in liquid

questions.subject: Reservoir Engineering - Phase Behavior
questions.explanation: Bubble point pressure is the pressure at which the first gas bubble appears as pressure decreases in an initially undersaturated oil.

questions.text: What is the typical range of oil well drilling depths?
questions.subject: Drilling Engineering - Well Depths
questions.explanation: Most oil wells are drilled to depths between 500 and 7000 meters, though some ultra-deep wells exceed 10,000 meters.

questions.text: Which recovery mechanism involves injecting water into the reservoir?
questions.subject: Production Engineering - Recovery Methods
questions.explanation: Waterflooding is a secondary recovery method where water is injected to maintain pressure and displace oil toward production wells.

questions.subject: Reservoir Engineering - Formation Volume Factor
questions.explanation: Formation volume factor (Bo, Bg) is the ratio of volume occupied by oil or gas at reservoir conditions to the volume at standard surface conditions.

questions.text: In rotary drilling, the kelly is used to:

options.text: Transmit rotary motion to drill string

questions.subject: Drilling Engineering - Rotary Drilling
questions.explanation: The kelly is a square or hexagonal pipe that transmits rotary motion from the rotary table to the drill string.

questions.text: What is the main purpose of well cementing?
questions.subject: Drilling Engineering - Well Cementing
questions.explanation: Primary cementing provides zonal isolation by sealing the annulus between casing and formation, preventing fluid migration.

questions.text: The bottom hole pressure in a flowing well is:
questions.subject: Production Engineering - Well Performance
questions.explanation: During production, bottom hole flowing pressure is less than reservoir pressure due to pressure drop required to flow fluids from reservoir to wellbore.

questions.text: Reservoir simulation is primarily used for:
questions.subject: Reservoir Engineering - Simulation
questions.explanation: Reservoir simulation models fluid flow in porous media to predict future production performance and optimize recovery strategies.

questions.text: Enhanced oil recovery (EOR) methods are applied during:
questions.subject: Production Engineering - EOR
questions.explanation: EOR methods are tertiary recovery techniques applied after primary and secondary methods to recover additional oil.
